node.title: COVID-19 Live Updates: Another 500,000 more deaths by February Predicted
node.description: The WHO has warned of a further 500,000 COVID-19 deaths between now and February as countries brace for a winter spike. Follow Newsweek's liveblog for all the latest.

node.title: College Football Playoff Rankings Are an Ode to the Power 5
node.description: The rankings showed how much organizers favor the most powerful teams in the sport, and they created a hurdle for Cincinnati, which has a marquee win and an undefeated record.

node.title: Turning Back the Clock
node.description: After a busy week, we offer six stories that caught our eyes.

node.title: Japan will shorten quarantine for business travelers to 3 days.
node.description: The easing of rules comes as cases decline significantly. The country has virtually closed its borders since the start of the pandemic.

node.title: 6 Companies Most Likely to Next Join Tesla on $1 Trillion Valuation
node.description: Elon Musk's company joined the exclusive $1 trillion club last week—joining Apple, Saudi Aramco, Microsoft, Amazon and Alphabet.

node.title: Multiple States Sue Joe Biden Administration Over Work Vaccine Mandates
node.description: Under the new rules, businesses with 100 employees or more are required to develop a mandatory vaccination and testing policy within 30 days.

node.title: David Pogue and his quest to make scientific achievements relatable
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, Pogue talks about the mission for his new podcast series "Unsung Science."

node.title: What To Know About NASA's Asteroid Impact Mission To Test Earth's Defences
node.description: Scientists want to know if smashing the DART spacecraft into the Dimorphos asteroid system at 15,000 miles per hour could protect our planet from possible future impacts.

node.title: Jim Jones Vows to Kill Whoever is Trying to Poison Him in Disturbing Audio
node.description: Jim Jones believed someone at Jonestown was trying to poison him, which is ironic given that he was planning to poison his entire congregation.

node.title: Feds scrap deal with company that made contaminated J&J COVID vaccine
node.description: Emergent BioSolutions says it will lose $180 million of the $600 million called for in the original contract, and says the decision was mutual.

node.title: Here’s what to watch for in the October jobs report.
node.description: Economists are looking for a gain of 450,000 positions, with a tailwind from hiring by leisure and hospitality businesses.

node.title: Wages are rising, but can they keep up with inflation?
node.description: In the tug of war between wage growth and rising prices, it is not yet clear who is winning. It could matter for the Fed.

node.title: Young Activists Want Action as Protesters Rally at COP26
node.description: For many, the climate conference has inspired mixed emotions: concern that their voices were not really being listened to, but also hope that their presence would help drive change.

node.title: Cancun Shooting Video Shows Resort Guests Hide As Armed Men Storm Beach
node.description: The group arrived by boat in front of resorts in Cancun on Mexico's Caribbean coast in an apparent fight between warring drug gangs.

node.title: New Jersey Truck Driver Edward Durr's Offensive Social Media Posts Emerge
node.description: The GOP candidate—who won a shock victory against Stephen Sweeney—previously called Islam a "cult of hate" and its prophet Muhammad a "pedophile" online.

node.title: Baby Gorilla at Ohio Zoo Adopted by Elder Female After Mom's Lack of Care
node.description: The young western lowland gorilla, the first to be born at Cleveland Zoo, is being cared for by the oldest female in the group, who takes it to be fed by humans.

node.title: Floods kill at least six people in Indonesia as thick mud hampers relief efforts
node.description: Flash flooding caused by torrential rains on Indonesia's main island of Java have killed at least six people, with three others missing.

node.title: Kangaroo Island Mayor storms out of parliamentary inquiry after refusing to answer lawyer's questions
node.description: Describing it as a "complete circus", Michael Pengilly storms out of a parliamentary committee looking into Vickie Chapman's refusal of a port on Kangaroo Island.

node.title: If you support Taiwan's independence, China won't let you into the mainland, Hong Kong, or Macau
node.description: The Chinese government says it has drawn up a list of people who support Taiwan's independence.

node.title: Beyond Ocean Views: Homes Perched on Cliffs
node.description: It takes some creative engineering — and a bit of daredevil spirit — to build a house that is truly waterside.

node.title: On the Portuguese Coast, an Appealing Spot for Seaside Homes
node.description: It wasn’t too long ago that Comporta was relatively unknown, but it’s seeing a spurt of development and now may be the time to buy.

node.title: Another Landmark Lost, This Time on Astor Row in Harlem
node.description: A building that is protected from demolition in New York City may seem safe, but decades of neglect and missed opportunities can take a toll.

node.title: An Adventure in the Conventional
node.description: Jessica Rosenblum was initially more interested in redecorating Steve Young’s loft apartment than she was in him.

node.title: Landmarks Aren’t Always Forever
node.description: Here are a few historic structures that were demolished and one that was spared after being declared a landmark at the 11th hour.

node.title: Their Love for Fun Inspired a Love for Each Other
node.description: Douglas Atkins and Charles Huck discovered that the only thing better than enjoying life is enjoying it as a couple.

node.title: The ‘Crush’ That Turned Into Something Much More
node.description: Ernest Owens and Barry Johnson met in 2013 at a Black fraternity party at the University of Pennsylvania, where both were students.

node.title: Former House Aides Try Making a Home of Their Own
node.description: Julia Tishman and Adam Elias fell fast for each other after connecting at a birthday-party-slash-networking-event when they worked on Capitol Hill.

node.title: When Art and Music Collide
node.description: While Brandon George was performing flute music to celebrate a new exhibit at the Met, he couldn’t help but notice the exhibit’s curator, Adam Eaker.

node.title: Vibing on Art and Artists’ Books
node.description: Gil Gentile asked Hannah Mandel on a first date to a conceptual art exhibit at the Jewish Museum. A year later they created an artist’s book as a nod to it.

node.title: ‘It Was Like My Pinterest Board Come to Life’
node.description: After Zachary Chan surprised Ashley Mungiguerra with a ring on a trip to Amsterdam, the two were married in a “secret garden.”

node.title: Michael Rubin’s Big Shot
node.description: Life isn’t all choppers and parties for the king of sports merch — he’s got plans.

node.title: Finding Love on the Overnight Shift
node.description: Averi Harper and Kenneth Robinson met on a San Francisco train six years ago. As luck would have it, they both had “unconventional schedules.”

node.title: Letters to the Editor on the 125th Anniversary Issue
node.description: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

node.title: Two Octogenarians Commit to ‘Living Apart Together’
node.description: Harry Mirra had no interest in remarrying after the death of his wife until Ginny Valonis, herself a widow, opened his mind to a union on their terms.

node.title: Memoirs of Womanhood by Emily Ratajkowski, Toufah Jallow and N. West Moss
node.description: Three autobiographical debuts reveal the pain and power of the female condition.

node.title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
node.description: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of “Spencer,” Pablo Larraín’s new film about Princess Diana.

node.title: An Illustrated History of Bad Art Friends
node.description: Is there a line between being inspired by others’ lives and stealing from them?

node.title: New in Paperback: ‘First Principles’ and ‘The Searcher’
node.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

node.title: Kristen Stewart’s Princess Diaries
node.description: The actress is drawing Oscar talk for her portrayal of Princess Diana in “Spencer,” a role that required the sort of performance she had never given before.

node.title: Marian Anderson: A Voice of Authenticity and Justice
node.description: A new box set explores the singer whose Lincoln Memorial concert was a 20th-century civil rights milestone.

node.title: For Barbora Krejcikova, Tennis Grew on Her
node.description: She first played for fun, but she has gone on to win the French Open and is half of a formidable doubles team.

node.title: Iga Swiatek, Voted a Fan Favorite, Turns to the Finals
node.description: She shocked the sport when she not only won the French Open, but dominated it. Building Legos helps her relax.

node.title: WTA Finals, a Nomadic Tournament, Lands in Mexico
node.description: A last-minute deal brings the event to Guadalajara. But what about that altitude?

node.title: 26.2 at 50
node.description: The New York City Marathon’s 50th running is on Sunday. This is the story of one race, five boroughs, dozens of champions and over a million hopeful runners.

node.title: Will World-Class Architecture Bring Civic Pride Back to Memphis?
node.description: Spurred by Herzog & de Meuron’s new art museum and a rethought waterfront park by Studio Gang, city leaders turn to design to make a downtown for “everyone.”

node.title: To Build the Metaverse, Meta First Wants to Build Stores
node.description: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.

node.title: What Happens if the Supreme Court Strikes Down New York’s Gun Law?
node.description: Legal experts said New York and several other states may have to rewrite laws, and officials expressed concern about the ramifications for public safety.

node.title: The Growing Appeal of a House on the Lake
node.description: Here are four up-and-coming destinations for buyers who want access to water sports in their front yard.

node.title: Dining Sheds Saved N.Y.C. Could They Destroy It?
node.description: The Lower East Side has turned into an all-night fraternity party, locals say, and small businesses are asking for help.

node.title: How the New York City Marathon’s Race Director Spends His Sundays
node.description: Although Ted Metellus runs only on weekdays, he is committed to making it happen this weekend for about 30,000 others.

node.title: In India, fears grow that gatherings for Diwali could prompt another virus spike.
node.description: Epidemiologists are concerned that Covid cases will surge after shoppers thronged markets and hundreds of thousands traveled around the country to celebrate the festival.

node.title: Energy Department Aims to Slash Cost of Removing Carbon From the Air
node.description: Scientists say carbon removal may be needed to avert the worst effects of climate change. But it still needs to be much cheaper and more reliable.

node.title: New York Becomes Marathon City Once Again
node.description: The marathon’s comeback from a pandemic that brought the city to a standstill will make it especially meaningful.

node.title: How Frequent Flier Programs Are Changing in a Changed World
node.description: In an era of climate change and virus concerns, it’s a challenging time to keep fliers loyal. Here is how U.S. airlines are trying to keep up.

node.title: Joe Manchin, Kyrsten Sinema, Know What Happened to Pols Who Did What They're Doing
node.description: It pays to oppose popular progressive programs: Big Business says yes to Democratic lawmakers who say no.

node.title: 'I'm Going to War; I'm Bringing the Big Cock,' Posted a Trump Fan. The FBI Didn't Notice
node.description: A threat to the country—to the peaceful transfer of power, a matter of national pride and stability for 200 years—was emerging.

node.title: Death row inmates sue Japan, saying same-day notification of executions is 'inhumane'
node.description: In what is believed to be a first, two prisoners facing the death penalty say the practice of being told they will be executed that day is illegal.

node.title: 'We can almost hear the grass growing': Outback NT gets a drenching
node.description: Some stations surpass their highest daily November rainfall, coming as a welcome relief for many after the Territory's third-warmest October on record.

node.title: Surge in Europe Covid-19 cases 'a warning shot' for world -  WHO
node.description: Germany has recorded almost 34,000 daily Covid cases in the past 24 hours, its highest number so far, in what the health minister is calling a "massive pandemic of the unvaccinated".

node.title: Remains are thought to be hiker missing in Rockies since 1983
node.description: Authorities say remains found in August 2020 were just declared to likely be those of West German mountaineer Rudi Moder and they consider the case closed.

node.title: 'Our family is whole again': Cleo's parents speak for the first time since her rescue
node.description: Cleo Smith's parents speak out for the first time since the four-year-old was rescued, saying they are "so thankful that our little girl is back within our arms".

node.title: Cambage escapes fine, suspension following Nigerian team incident
node.description: Opals star Liz Cambage is handed a formal reprimand after an independent review finds she "brought Basketball Australia into censure" during a pre-Olympic clash with Nigeria.

node.title: Football great and Port Adelaide veteran Russell Ebert dies at age 72
node.description: Port Adelaide Football Club veteran and football great Russell Ebert has died from leukemia at the age of 72.

node.title: ABBA releases new comeback album Voyage after 40-year hiatus
node.description: Swedish pop sensation ABBA has made a comeback with their new album Voyage, nearly 40 years after they split up, with a digital avatar concert eventually planned in London.

node.title: Tourism operators 'skating on jelly' amid restrictions
node.description: Tourism operators that rely on a summer influx of Aucklanders fear a death knell if travel restrictions are not lifted by Christmas.

node.title: A Nuclear-Powered Shower? Russia Tests a Climate Innovation.
node.description: A remote Siberian town now has its own miniature nuclear plant as a Russian state company tests a new model for residential heating. Some see it as a tool to minimize climate change.

node.title: ‘Love Hard’ Review: Seeking Connection, Not Perfection
node.description: When a perennially single journalist travels across the country to meet her dream guy, she finds she’s been catfished.

node.title: 'Game on': Tourism critical of WA's roadmap while business calls on community to get vaccinated
node.description: There's a mixed reaction to the government's roadmap to opening WA's borders, with tourism operators expressing disappointment and the business lobby urging the community to get vaccinated.

node.title: 'I didn't sleep last night': Residents devastated by compulsory acquisition of homes for North-South Corridor
node.description: The state government has sent letters to residents whose properties will be compulsorily acquired as part of the last installment of the North-South Corridor.

node.title: Lost moose leaps through classroom window in Canada
node.description: Students in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan got an up-close lesson on the animal kingdom yesterday, when a moose crashed through the window of their school.

node.title: Covid-19: Two separate attempts to flee MIQ in Hamilton and Auckland
node.description: A Covid-19 case fled a Hamilton MIQ facility this morning by removing a section of fencing and jumping into a waiting car, but were stopped by police a few minutes later, in the second fleeing…

node.title: COP26: Indonesia criticises 'unfair' deal to end deforestation
node.description: Indonesia has criticised the terms of a global deal to end deforestation by 2030, signalling that the country may not abide by it.

node.title: Western Australian man charged with abducting Cleo Smith
node.description: A 36-year-old man faces court after being charged over the abduction of four-year-old Cleo Smith during a family camping trip.

node.title: South Dunedin double murderer sentenced to life
node.description: A Dunedin man who murdered a couple and then set their house alight has been sentenced to life imprisonment.

node.title: Sugar recall leaves cookie business in crumbs
node.description: A major sugar recall is hitting businesses big time - with those who ply their trade with sugar having to dump it in huge quantities.

node.title: Scott Morrison COP26 gaffe goes viral on Chinese social media
node.description: Scott Morrison's cops a backlash on Chinese social media after referring to "global momentum to tackle China" instead of "climate change" during a COP26 speech.

node.title: Reserve Bank sees wage growth hitting fastest pace in years — by 2023
node.description: The RBA says Australia's economy is recovering strongly from recent lockdowns, which bodes well for employment and wages growth.

node.title: Jimmy Kimmel: ‘Aaron Is a Karen’
node.description: As Covid sidelined the Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, Kimmel and other hosts scorned him for implying that he’d been vaccinated.

node.title: Gold Coast must lift jab 'game', Palaszczuk says, as schoolies vax hubs considered
node.description: The Premier has taken aim at flagging rates on the border as the government prepares a social media campaign to target young people who haven't been immunised.

node.title: Father-of-three handed five-year jail term over $500k tax fraud
node.description: An Adelaide man who made up employers and income to defraud the Australian Tax Office out of half a million dollars has been jailed for five years.

node.title: Sydney's inner west light rail shut down for up to 18 months because of cracks
node.description: NSW Transport Minister Rob Stokes announces all 12 light rail vehicles that make up the inner west service will be out of action after cracks were found last month.

node.title: Laughs No More? Australians Are Reassessing a Beloved Cartoonist.
node.description: I used to think Michael Leunig’s drawings embodied the soul of our nation. Now, I’m not so sure.

node.title: Tairāwhiti state of emergency lifted after flooding
node.description: The state of emergency in Tairāwhiti has this afternoon been lifted after three days of torrential rain.

node.title: Fire in historic Christchurch building leads to evacuations
node.description: A derelict building in Christchurch caught fire for the second time in three years this morning - forcing some to evacuate their homes.

node.title: DOC investigating death of 11 fur seals in Kaikōura
node.description: The deaths of eleven fur seals in Kaikōura are being treated as suspicious.

node.title: Israel Moves to Silence the Stalwarts of Palestinian Civil Society
node.description: These human rights activists are not terrorists.

node.title: A US nuclear-powered attack submarine hit something underwater – now its two senior officers have been fired
node.description: The USS Connecticut, a nuclear-powered fast-attack submarine, was reported to have struck an "object" underwater in early October under the busy shipping lanes of the South China Sea.

node.title: NT government pulls vaccination stats from website, admits remote region data was inflated
node.description: The Northern Territory government removes regional vaccine data from its website after being asked why there was a discrepancy of more than 50 per cent compared to the federal government's figures.

node.title: Jordan De Goey to 'vigorously defend himself' after being charged in the US
node.description: The Collingwood AFL player releases a statement via his lawyer after being charged in the United States last weekend.

node.title: New Antarctica NZ base to be built in Timaru
node.description: The entire base will be built at Timaru's port over a six-year period and will then shipped to Antarctica in eight modules on a massive ship.

node.title: Johnson & Johnson loses bid to take pelvic mesh appeal to High Court
node.description: Pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson has its bid for an appeal to a Federal Court ruling thrown out of the High Court.

node.title: Deputy PM on time slots for Christmas travel: 'It wouldn't be very practical'
node.description: Aucklanders will probably have a better option than allocated time to leave the region over the holidays, the deputy prime minister says. Audio

node.title: What Does War Feel Like to a Child?
node.description: “How War Changed Rondo,” a picture book by the Ukrainian artists Romana Romanyshyn and Andriy Lesiv, captures the unrelenting destructiveness of wartime as a young person experiences it.

node.title: Steve Sheinkin’s Explosive Sequel to ‘Bomb’
node.description: “Fallout: Spies, Superbombs, and the Ultimate Cold War Showdown” offers a whirlwind account of events leading up to the Cuban missile crisis.

node.title: The Curious Tale of Mr. Kale
node.description: He was everything I expected and wanted. So why hasn’t he returned to Whole Foods?

node.title: Your Friday Briefing
node.description: A Covid hot spot in Italy.

node.title: Atlanta Had to Celebrate Its Title Without Its Architect
node.description: Home after testing positive for the coronavirus, Alex Anthopoulos missed the party that wouldn’t have been possible without his brilliant deadline maneuvers.

node.title: House with window to the stars wins top architectural prize
node.description: An accessible custom-designed home in the NSW Blue Mountains, whose roof opens to a view of the milky way, wins a top prize as one of the nation's best designed homes — the Robin Boyd Award for Residential Architecture.

node.title: NASA unveils asteroid-fighting spacecraft as it prepares for Armageddon-style mission test
node.description: The spacecraft will be launched later this month on a test mission to determine whether crashing into an asteroid can change its trajectory.

node.title: ABC announces more jobs, funding for regional and rural journalism
node.description: Managing director David Anderson says the cash injection will allow bureaus to deliver more local content across platforms.
